 At the genomic level, yes, mutation occurs and for some this may constitute evolution (it does for me) but is this noticable or even relevant? I don't think so. Evolution requires either random (drift) or preferential (selection) survival of alleles within a population. 
 
 Random evolution (drift) continues to persist however, its effects are minimal at best.
 
 Preferential evolution (selection) has been denied by modern medicine (to some extent), which interrupts and complicates the kind of evolution that physiologically we would notice.
 
 So are we continuing to evolve? To a molecular biologist... technically yes. However, my point is that the social-behavioural interactions that we continue to replicate and modify are subject to greater selection than our genome at this point. This (and technology) are the extension of our reproductive process and it is here where evolution is now applying greater change.
